Inference: High anomaly frequency indicates persistent leakage or misuse
Description: Repeated flow anomaly alerts over short intervals suggest an ongoing issue such as a small continuous leak, a partially open faucet, or repeated overuse beyond historically normal levels.
short rationale: Signals ongoing misuse or leaks linked to occupants, enabling behavioral profiling.

Inference: Single-fixture–dominated anomalies point to localized hardware problems
Description: If most flow anomaly alerts are tied to the same smart faucet or showerhead, it indicates that specific fixture may have a faulty valve, worn cartridge, or usage pattern that regularly drives usage beyond the learned baseline.
short rationale: Hardware-focused signal with limited behavior exposure.

Inference: Long-duration anomalies imply unattended flow or runaway usage
Description: Flow anomalies that persist for unusually long periods compared to typical events indicate scenarios like someone forgetting to turn off a tap, a stuck handle, or a continuously running shower.
short rationale: Reveals negligence or unattended activity windows, showing routine gaps.

Inference: Short, high-intensity anomalies reflect burst-like activities
Description: Very brief but frequent flow anomaly alerts hint at activities such as rapid on–off cleaning bursts or handwashing sessions that momentarily exceed what the system learned as normal.
short rationale: Hints at brief cleaning or handwashing with low identity risk.

Inference: Night-time anomalies suggest leaks or unauthorized usage patterns
Description: Flow anomaly alerts clustered in historically low-usage windows, such as late night, indicate likely leaks, unintended drips, or potentially unauthorized access.
short rationale: Exposes sleep or absence schedule, useful for profiling or targeting.

Inference: Early-morning anomaly clusters reveal shifting routine intensity
Description: When anomalies concentrate around the same morning window, it suggests that daily hygiene routines have become more water-intensive than what the baseline model considered normal.
short rationale: Reveals morning routine intensity and timing.

Inference: Weekend-skewed anomalies reveal schedule-dependent water demand
Description: Flow anomaly alerts appearing more on weekends than weekdays suggest that users engage in water-heavy activities when they have more free time, pushing usage beyond weekday-learned patterns.
short rationale: Shows weekly availability patterns tied to personal routines.

Inference: Post-installation anomaly spikes signal threshold miscalibration
Description: A surge in flow anomaly alerts immediately after installation or configuration reset indicates that the normal pattern model is still learning or miscalibrated.
short rationale: Mostly calibration noise with negligible personal insight.

Inference: Declining anomaly trend indicates effective mitigation or behavior change
Description: A gradual reduction in flow anomaly alerts over time suggests that leaks were fixed, user education worked, or automatic optimizations aligned usage with the learned norm.
short rationale: Suggests behavior change but without granular routine detail.

Inference: Sudden anomaly surge flags recent behavioral or plumbing changes
Description: A sharp increase in flow anomaly alerts after a stable period implies a recent change such as new occupants, altered routines, or newly introduced fixtures.
short rationale: Signals lifestyle or occupancy shifts that can profile users.

Inference: High anomaly rate during absence windows suggests latent leaks
Description: If anomaly alerts frequently occur when the space is normally unoccupied, it strongly points to unattended leaks rather than normal user activity.
short rationale: Reveals when the space is unoccupied, creating security and privacy risk.

Inference: Repeated anomalies just above thresholds indicate overly tight baselines
Description: A pattern where many alerts are only marginally above the normal threshold suggests the baseline may be too strict and requires adjustment.
short rationale: Primarily shows model strictness rather than user behavior.

Inference: Fixture-mix anomalies reveal which outlets are most water-intensive
Description: When anomalies are disproportionately triggered by specific outlet types, it highlights where behavior or configuration consistently drives excessive water use.
short rationale: Highlights preferred outlets but without exact routines.

Inference: Clustered anomalies across fixtures indicate system-wide issues
Description: If several faucets and showerheads generate anomaly alerts in the same time windows, it hints at building-level effects such as pressure changes or simultaneous high demand.
short rationale: Indicates system-wide plumbing effects, not personal usage.

Inference: Seasonal anomaly variation indicates climate- or habit-driven changes
Description: More frequent flow anomalies during specific seasons suggest seasonal habits that increase water usage beyond what patterns from other seasons predict.
short rationale: Shows seasonal habit shifts but coarse granularity.

Inference: Persistent low-severity anomalies point to micro-leaks or drips
Description: Many small anomalies that barely exceed the norm and occur repeatedly hint at continuous low-level flows such as dripping faucets or slowly leaking fittings.
short rationale: Implies minor leaks with limited personal context.

Inference: High-severity anomalies flag potential burst pipe or fully open tap scenarios
Description: Rare but very large deviations from normal usage suggest serious incidents like burst pipes, fully open taps, or showers left running for extended periods.
short rationale: Captures rare emergencies more than identifiable behavior.

Inference: Anomalies aligned with fixed routines reveal stable high-intensity habits
Description: When anomaly alerts consistently occur at the same times and locations, it indicates a stable routine that is inherently more water-intensive than the learned norm.
short rationale: Exposes precise repeated high-intensity daily habits.

Inference: Randomly timed anomalies imply stochastic events
Description: Flow anomaly alerts that appear at irregular times with no clear pattern are more likely due to unpredictable events such as ad-hoc cleaning or guest usage.
short rationale: Unpatterned events carry little identifiable information.

Inference: Anomaly patterns migrating between fixtures indicate shifting preferences
Description: If the main source of anomalies moves from one fixture to another over time, it suggests users have changed preferred locations or usage habits.
short rationale: Shows shifting location preferences over time, enabling behavioral mapping.

Inference: Anomaly absence in certain fixtures indicates underutilization or conservative use
Description: If some smart faucets or showerheads never trigger flow anomaly alerts while others do, it implies those devices operate strictly within normal bounds.
short rationale: Reveals underused fixtures but minimal routine detail.

Inference: Persistent anomalies after interventions suggest hidden faults
Description: When alerts continue despite attempted fixes, it indicates that the root cause may be elsewhere, such as hidden plumbing issues upstream of the fixture.
short rationale: Focuses on hidden faults rather than user actions.

Inference: Burst-like anomaly clusters suggest cleaning or bulk-use sessions
Description: Many anomalies concentrated in a narrow time window suggest water-intensive activities like cleaning sessions or multiple back-to-back showers.
short rationale: Suggests cleaning sessions with limited personal detail.

Inference: Anomalies decreasing after recommendations imply user responsiveness
Description: If flow anomaly frequency declines after feedback or alerts, it indicates that users are adapting their behavior to stay within normal ranges.
short rationale: Indicates responsiveness but not detailed behavior traces.

Inference: Stable anomaly baseline over long periods signals predictable high-demand usage
Description: A consistent rate of flow anomalies over months implies a steady state where users habitually use more water than the statistical norm without underlying faults.
short rationale: Shows consistently high usage tied to occupants' habits.
